fields.headline: Cashpoints: House prices stall while remortgaging soars
fields.bodyText: IN CASHPOINTS TODAY · First-time buyers prompt slowdown in property market · Madeleine Bunting on why work is bad for your health · Dr Work answers your questions May 1: Growth in house prices stalls House prices ground to a halt last month - the first time they have not increased since October 2001, Nationwide building society said yesterday. Story in full On Guardian Unlimited Money More on house prices OTHER NEWS April 29: Low-rate loans lead to surge in remortgaging Figures released by the British Bankers' Association show that remortgaging soared by 53% from March 2002 with a record 89,999 loans approved last month. Story in full On Guardian Unlimited Money More on mortgages April 29: Self-employed could lose out under child tax credit system Self-employed parents whose income suddenly drops due to illness, bad debts or a downturn in their business could miss out on hundreds of pounds because of an "iniquitous" loophole in the new child tax credit, it was claimed today. Story in full On Guardian Unlimited Money More on tax · Do you have any feedback on any of these issues that you want get off your chest? Email us at money.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk COLUMNIST It's official: according to the Mental Health Foundation, work is bad for you. So why do we do it, asks Madeleine Bunting. "According to the Mental Health Foundation's 'Who's Life Is It Anyway?' report, work's corrosive effect on our lives is widespread. Their survey uncovered 'a picture of loss on a large scale': relationship breakdown, loss of friendship, poor relationships with children, not being able to spend time with a terminally ill friend or relative - even cases where long hours at work precluded people from having a child or meeting a partner in the first place. "Such is the extent of this problem that one has to ask: why on earth are we all putting up with it? According to the DTI's 2002 survey, twice as many employees reported that they would rather work shorter hours than win the lottery. What is so intriguing about this problem is that the people who work some of the longest hours and complain the most bitterly about it, are the very people who have the most leverage within the labour market. Why is it that the most talented and skilled seem the least able to exercise their own power?" Read her piece in full ASK THE EXPERTS Question of the week "I have two pensions from previous employers but do not have any paperwork/policy numbers from either. How would I go about locating and claiming them?" Dr Work, our work expert, says: "I suggest that you contact the Pension Schemes Registry, part of the Occupational Pensions Regulatory Authority (Opra), which may be able to trace the addresses of your pension schemes. Also, do not overlook the simple expedient of contacting the pension trustees." Read his answer in full here · Any questions?
